message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Self-Triggered Fuzzy Bipartite Time-Varying Formation Tracking for Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Deferred Asymmetric Output Constraints
Paper Abstract: In this paper, an adaptive fuzzy bipartite formation tracking control strategy of nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs) is developed under a directed communication topology. Fuzzy logic systems are utilized to approximate the unknown nonlinear dynamics. Then, considering MASs with both cooperative and competitive relationships, the proposed bipartite formation tracking strategy allows each agent to operate according to their specific advantages. By employing a nonlinear state transformation function, the original constrained outputs of the MASs are converted into unconstrained ones. Meanwhile, a prescribed-time shifting function is introduced to handle the deferred output constraints, by which the singularity problem generated from the denominator of nonlinear state transformation functions is avoided. In addition, considering the communication bandwidth is limited, a distributed dynamic self-triggered control (DSTC) mechanism is constructed to improve the transmission efficiency. Different from the traditional self-triggered control strategy, the proposed DSTC strategy allows triggered intervals to be adjusted dynamically according to bipartite formation tracking errors, which enables the DSTC strategy to compromise communication burdern and system performances dynamically. Finally, two simulation examples are given to illustrate the validity of the proposed control scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about **formation control**:

Formation control is a field of study in robotics research dealing with the control of robotic systems. The search results show that this is a technical area within the broader discipline of robotics and control engineering.

The most relevant result mentions that M. Anthony Lewis is known for his work in evolutionary and biomorphic robotics, formation control of robotic systems, and investigations into the basis of movement control in humans and robots.

While the search results don't provide extensive detail about formation control specifically, the concept relates to coordinating and controlling the movement and positioning of multiple robotic agents or systems to maintain a desired formation or pattern. This is typically studied as a subfield of control theory and multi-agent robotics.

If you're looking for more specific technical details about formation control algorithms, applications, or methodologies, I'd recommend searching for more specialized resources on multi-agent robotics or control systems.

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have autonomy and are at least partially independent and self-aware, with no agent designated as controlling the system.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the system's communication protocol, such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL), the approach may lead to common improvement.

## Types of Agents

The agents in a multi-agent system could be robots, humans, human teams, or combined human-agent teams.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Modern Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Web search results for query: "Nonlinear system control"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Dead-beat control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead-beat_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear Dynamics (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_Dynamics_(journal)"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear system control:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle and are governed by linear differential equations. In contrast, nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Characteristics of Nonlinear Systems

Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition, may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.

## Analysis and Design Approaches

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, and include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.

## Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system, where a building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off".

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle and are governed by linear differential equations. In contrast, nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Characteristics of Nonlinear Systems

Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition, may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.

## Analysis and Design Approaches

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, and include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.

## Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system, where a building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off".

I've completed the web search for "Distributed control systems." Here's what I found:

## Overview

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

## Key Characteristics

The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.(no content)This distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

## Applications and Benefits

DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.(no content)The introduction of DCSs allowed easy interconnection and re-configuration of plant controls such as cascaded loops and interlocks, and easy interfacing with other production computer systems. It enabled sophisticated alarm handling, introduced automatic event logging, removed the need for physical records such as chart recorders, allowed the control racks to be networked and thereby located locally to plant to reduce cabling runs, and provided high level overviews of plant status and production levels.

## Fuzzy Logic - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about fuzzy logic. Here are the key results:

### Definition and Core Concept

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic in which the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.(no content)It is employed to handle the concept of partial truth, where the truth value may range between completely true and completely false. This contrasts with Boolean logic, where the truth values of variables may only be the integer values 0 or 1.

### Historical Background

The term fuzzy logic was introduced with the 1965 proposal of fuzzy set theory by mathematician Lotfi Zadeh.(no content)Basic fuzzy logic had, however, been studied since the 1920s, as infinite-valued logic—notably by Łukasiewicz and Tarski.

### Practical Applications

Fuzzy logic has been applied to many fields, from control theory to artificial intelligence.(no content)Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure".(no content)Firms such as Boeing, General Motors, Allen-Bradley, Chrysler, Eaton, and Whirlpool have worked on fuzzy logic for use in low-power refrigerators, improved automotive transmissions, and energy-efficient electric motors.

### Advantages

Fuzzy logic has the advantage that the solution to the problem can be cast in terms that human operators can understand, such that their experience can be used in the design of the controller.

## Adaptive Control - Search Results

Here's what I found about adaptive control:

### Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Types of Adaptive Control

Several broad categories include Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) that incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance, and Model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs) that perform system identification while the system is running.

### Recent Developments

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.

## Adaptive Control - Search Results

Here's what I found about adaptive control:

### Definition

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

### Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

### Types of Adaptive Control

Several broad categories include Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) that incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance, and Model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs) that perform system identification while the system is running.

### Recent Developments

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.

Web search results for query: "Feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Control–feedback–abort loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control%E2%80%93feedback%E2%80%93abort_loop"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's what feedback control is:

## Definition

A feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

In feedback control, the control action from the controller is dependent on the process output. The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Practical Example

A common everyday example is cruise control on a road vehicle, where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Key Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

The key concept is that feedback control continuously monitors the system's output and adjusts the control inputs based on how far the actual output is from the desired target, allowing for automatic corrections and adaptation.

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystrokes"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_driven_programming"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trauma_trigger"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about **event-triggered control**:

Event-triggered control is a field of study related to the analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, was recognized as an IEEE Fellow in 2016 for his contributions to this area.

Event-triggered control is distinct from time-triggered approaches. While time-triggered systems execute tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, event-triggered control systems respond to specific events or state changes rather than fixed time intervals.

This approach is particularly relevant in modern control systems where:
- An event can be defined as "a significant change in state"
- The system needs to respond efficiently to meaningful changes without continuous periodic updates
- Resources can be conserved by only updating when necessary

Event-triggered control is used in various applications including networked systems, hybrid systems, and embedded systems where efficient resource utilization and responsive behavior are important considerations.

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability; often with the aim to achieve a degree of optimality.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering (dealing with process control systems for robotics and industry), control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering (dealing with process control systems for robotics and industry), control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper and extracted all key technologies and methodologies. Here's a summary:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes novel control strategies)

**8 Triples Identified:**

1. **Fuzzy logic** (method) - Uses fuzzy logic systems to approximate unknown nonlinear dynamics
2. **Multi-agent system** (task) - Proposes bipartite formation tracking control strategy for MAS
3. **Nonlinear control** (method) - Proposes control strategies for nonlinear MAS using fuzzy logic and state transformations
4. **Adaptive control** (method) - Proposes adaptive fuzzy bipartite formation tracking that adjusts to system parameters
5. **Control theory** (concept) - Applies control theory principles for formation tracking and self-triggered mechanisms
6. **Distributed control system** (method) - Proposes distributed dynamic self-triggered control mechanism for communication efficiency
7. **Feedback control** (method) - Uses feedback control principles where agents adjust based on tracking errors
8. **Fuzzy control system** (method) - Proposes adaptive fuzzy control system for handling constrained outputs

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The analysis shows this is a control systems paper that combines fuzzy logic, adaptive control, and distributed mechanisms to solve the problem of formation tracking in multi-agent systems with both cooperative and competitive relationships.

Sources:
- [Fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Distributed control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system)
- [Feedback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback)
- [Fuzzy control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system)
